'''Open content''' or '''OpenContent''' is a [[neologism]] coined by [[David A. Wiley|David Wiley]] in 1998{{Cite news | last = Grossman| first = Lev| title = New Free License to Cover Content Online| work = Netly News| accessdate = 2010-01-12| date = 1998-07-18| url = http://www.time.com/time/digital/daily/0,2822,621,00.html |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20000619122406/http://www.time.com/time/digital/daily/0,2822,621,00.html |archivedate = 2000-06-19}} which describes a [[creative work]] that others can copy or modify. The term evokes [[open source]], which is a related concept in software.{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2010-01-12| year = 1998| url = http://web.archive.org/web/19990429221830/www.opencontent.org/home.shtml}} When the term OpenContent was first used by Wiley, it described works licensed under the [[Open Content License]] (a [[copyleft]] licence) and perhaps other works licensed under similar terms.{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2010-01-12| year = 1998| url = http://web.archive.org/web/19990429221830/www.opencontent.org/home.shtml}} It has since come to describe a broader class of content without conventional copyright restrictions. The openness of content can be assessed under the '4Rs Framework' based on the extent to which it can be reused, revised, remixed and redistributed by members of the public without violating copyright law.{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opencontent.org/definition/}} Unlike [[open source]] and [[free content]], there is no clear threshold that a work must reach to qualify as 'open content'. Although open content has been described as a counterbalance to [[copyright]],[http://www.apdip.net/publications/fosseprimers/foss-opencontent-nocover.pdf Lawrence Liang, "Free/Open Source Software Open Content", ''Asia-Pacific Development Information Programme: e-Primers on Free/Open Source Software'', United Nations Development Programme â Asia-Pacific Development Information Programme, 2007.] open content licences rely on a copyright holder's power to license their work. == Definition == The OpenContent website once defined OpenContent as 'freely available for modification, use and redistribution under a license similar to those used by the Open Source / Free Software community',{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Defining the 'Open' in Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opencontent.org/definition/}} that is to say, a libre licence which allows commercial adaptation of the work as well as its distribution. It is unclear if OpenContent was used to exclusively describe content licensed under the [[Open Content Licence]] (OPL) or if OPL content was a subset of OpenContent. The term since shifted in meaning, and the OpenContent website now describes openness as a 'continuous construct'.{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Defining the 'Open' in Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opencontent.org/definition/}} The more copyright permissions are granted to the general public, the more open the content is. The threshold for open content is simply that the work 'is licensed in a manner that provides users with the right to make more kinds of uses than those normally permitted under the law - at no cost to the user.'{{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Defining the 'Open' in Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opencontent.org/definition/}} The 4Rs are put forward on the OpenContent website as a framework for assessing the extent to which content is open:
# Reuse - the right to reuse the content in its unaltered / verbatim form (e.g., make a backup copy of the content) # Revise - the right to adapt, adjust, modify, or alter the content itself (e.g., translate the content into another language) # Remix - the right to combine the original or revised content with other content to create something new (e.g., incorporate the content into a mashup) # Redistribute - the right to share copies of the original content, your revisions, or your remixes with others (e.g., give a copy of the content to a friend){{Cite web | last = Wiley| first = David| title = Defining the 'Open' in Open Content| work = OpenContent.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opencontent.org/definition/}}
This broader definition distinguishes open content from open source software, since the latter must be available for commercial use and adaptation by the public. However, it is similar to several definitions for [[open educational resources]], which include resources under noncommercial and verbatim licences.ï»¿{{Cite conference | publisher = The William and Flora Hewlett Foundation | last = Atkins | first = Daniel E. | coauthors = John Seely Brown, Allen L. Hammond | title = A Review of the Open Educational Resources (OER) Movement: Achievements, Challenges, and New Opportunities | location = Menlo Park, CA | date = 2007-02 | accessdate = 2010-12-03 | page = 4 | url = http://www.hewlett.org/uploads/files/Hewlett_OER_report.pdf }}{{cite conference|first = Guntram|last= Geser|title= Open Educational Practices and Resources. OLCOS Roadmap 2012|place= Salzburg, Austria|publisher=[[Salzburg Research]], EduMedia Group|date= 2007-01|page=20|accessdate = 2010-11-06 |url=http://www.olcos.org/english/roadmap/download/index.htm}} The Open Definition, which purports to define open content and [[open knowledge]], draws heavily on the Open Source Definition; it preserves the limited sense of open content as libre content.{{Cite web | title = Open Definition| work = OpenDefinition.org| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://opendefinition.org/okd/}} ==Free content and free documentation== {{Main|free content}} As with [[alternative terms for free software|the terms "open source" and "free software"]], some open content materials can also be described as "[[free content]]". However, free content has preserved the requirement (present in both open source and free software) that licences allow commercial use and adaptation. For similar reasons, the [[Free Software Foundation]] describes the Open Content License as a non-free documentation licence.{{Cite web | author = Free Software Foundation | title = Various Licenses and Comments Upon Them| accessdate = 2011-11-18| url = http://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html#NonFreeDocumentationLicenses}} ==Open access== "[[Open access (publishing)|Open access]]" refers to toll-free or [[gratis]] access to content, consisting mainly of published [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] scholarly journal articles.
